description.narrative: Develop and conduct needs assessments, baseline studies, targeted evaluations, special studies or other information-gathering efforts specifically for the design, monitoring and evaluation of USG-funded programs. This sub-element may also include developing and disseminating best practices and lessons learned, testing demonstration and/or pilot models, or the preparation of strategic plans and other short-term programming tasks. Note: All such activities that are carried out by partners as an integral part of their monitoring and evaluation efforts for programs funded under other sub-elements should be included within those sub-elements.

description.narrative: Sustain the productivity of the agricultural sector through investments that foster increasing returns to land, labor, and capital. Targeted interventions to male and female producers provide improvements in technology and management practices, expanded access to markets and credit, increased organizational and market efficiency, and restoration and protection of resiliency in production and livelihood systems.

description.narrative: Supports the following illustrative program-funded costs: salaries of US, FSN, and TCN and other staff such as PSCs, RSSAs, PASAs, CASUs working for the US Government managing, administering, and supporting programs and their program-funded benefits such as housing, travel, transportation, education allowances etc; institutional contractors that provide such staff, rent, IT services, the program-funded share of utilities, staff training costs and the cost of developing and administering training programs, equipment and supplies, ICASS, vehicle fuel and maintenance, maintenance contracts, janitorial services, operational unit web page development and maintenance, outreach such as publications and the cost of their preparation (including staff costs), and technical assistance to ensure USG compliance with regulations.

usg:treasury-account.usg:main-account: Assistance for Europe, Eurasia and Central Asia (AEECA)

title.narrative: Civic Education, Citizen Participation and Public Accountability

description.narrative: Support activities that advance citizen engagement to hold governments accountable and to participate actively in economic, political, governing and other critical processes aimed at creating more peaceful, democratic, and pluralistic societies. Promote citizen engagement in local decision-making processes, such as through participatory budgeting processes and public-private dialog for economic development priorities. Examples of other activities include, supporting CSO and citizen advocacy efforts; backing citizen monitoring and oversight initiatives; and strengthening citizen engagement in service delivery. Activities in this element relate to the role of civil society in holding public institutions accountable (the watchdog role) whereas DR.2.2 is focused on assistance to public institutions to increase their accountability.

title.narrative: Strengthening Civil Society and Independent Media in Belarus

description.narrative: The Strengthening Civil Society, Civic Engagement and Independent Media in Belarus Program seeks to increase the number and effectiveness of citizens engaging in Belarus civil society by strengthening formal and informal civic groups, as well as the capabilities of individuals, to address issues of public concern at both local and national levels, thereby strengthening the culture of civic participation and increasing the flow of, and access to, independent information.

title.narrative: USAID redacted this field in accordance with the exceptions outlined in the Foreign Aid Transparency and Accountability Act of 2016.

description.narrative: This USAID activity advances U.S. economic security by promoting market-oriented economic and government reforms and aligns with JSP Goal 2.3 and ICS MO 1.2. The activity helps grow private innovative business in Belarus while developing the venture financing (VF) market. AID-VENTURE helps develop the legal and regulatory framework conducive to venture funding; establishes a community of business angels and venture investors; and creates mechanisms for attracting capital and channeling investments to startups; all to integrate Belarus into the international VF ecosystem. USAID's efforts focus on increasing the role of the private sector in the economy to improve the country's market diversificationUSAID's Small and Medium Enterprise (SME) development and export market diversification efforts help create better opportunities for U.S. investments in Belarus. FY 2018 funds will support Association Belbiz, a local leader and trend setter in the startup market. AID-VENTURE will continue regulatory consultancy on the needed legislative changes conducive for VF. The partner will work with the Business Angels Network and train 20 business angels in best investment practices; support the TechMinsk startup school to make emerging startups investment ready; and conduct large-scale hackathons, master classes, educational, and networking events. FY 2018 funds will support 300 firms in improving their business performance. In the traditionally male-dominated ICT sector, USAID seeks to ensure greater female participation. USAID will also support nationwide forums promoting entrepreneurship, such as Global Entrepreneurship Week and Venture Day, for 1,500 and 600 people, respectively. AID-VENTURE will focus on helping to connect fragmented local players, while improving their capacity for creating startups and a vibrant SME ecosystem to help bring Belarus down the path to self-reliance.

receiver-org.narrative: Asociacija Belbiz

description.narrative: Strengthen the legal, regulatory, institutional, and information environment which protects and enables the growth in associational life and the development of independent and sustainable civil society organizations (CSOs). Build the capacity of civil society organizations to act as agents for reform and support their participation in democratic decision-making through articulating and representing their members interests, engaging in service delivery, and advocating for issues which become part of the public agenda and are reflected in public policies. Encourage the strengthening of a civic culture which supports democratic institutions and processes, active participation in political and civic life, and the civic virtues of tolerance, pluralism, compromise, trust, and respect for individual rights, including gender equality.

receiver-org.narrative: World Learning, Inc.

description.narrative: The Community Connections Program (CCP) in Belarus is an exchange program that supports U.S. public diplomacy goals and builds and promotes mutual understanding between the American and Belarusian people. The program provides Belarusian professionals in business, education, law, civil society, and government the opportunity to gain practical experience from their American counterparts within their respective fields. The program lasts three weeks and includes site visits to American governmental agencies, businesses and civil society organizations.

description.narrative: Improve the capacity of businesses to integrate into domestic and international markets through increases in productivity and improvements in corporate governance and the development and application of modern technology and marketing practices. Enhance the capacity of businesses and business associations in terms of their corporate governance capabilities and their application of best practices and technologies to achieve increased production and marketing of products and services. It includes adoption of efficient production processes, improved labor productivity, environmentally-sound management of natural resources and the development of accounting and management systems that can help the company and industry group implement business, labor, product and process standards that enhance business competitiveness. Business capacity development programs may include activities that help men- and women-owned firms and associations respond to these international markets and create regional alliances.

Objectives for Belarus: Program Objectives: Increase the competitiveness of the private sector and its contribution to the Belarusian economy by: 1) Improving the business enabling environment for MSMEs. 2)Strengthening the capacity of MSMEs. 3) Increasing access to finance.

description.narrative: Improve the capacity of businesses, including the self-employed poor; micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs); and high growth potential entrepreneurs, to start or grow and integrate into domestic and international markets through increases in productivity and improvements in corporate governance and the development and application of modern technology and marketing practices. Enhance the capacity of businesses and business associations in terms of their corporate governance capabilities and their application of best practices and technologies to achieve increased production and marketing of products and services. It includes adoption of efficient production processes, improved labor productivity, environmentally-sound management of natural resources and the development of accounting and management systems that can help the company and industry group implement business, labor, product and process standards that enhance business competitiveness. Business capacity development programs may include activities that help men- and women-owned firms and associations respond to these international markets and create regional alliances.

description.narrative: LEED will support the development and growth of private micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs). title.narrative: Countering Trafficking in Persons in Belarus

description.narrative: This activity aims to build Belarus's national capacity to prevent trafficking in persons (TIP) and provide comprehensive assistance to victims of trafficking (VOTs). It aligns with the Joint Strategic Plan (JSP) Goal 1.3 and ICS Mission Objective (MO) 1.1. Following recommendations of the Department of State (DOS) TIP Report, USAID works to reduce the level of TIP in Belarus by strengthening the National Referral Mechanism (NRM), a cooperative framework for state actors to coordinate their efforts with civil society, and build the capacity of local civil society organizations (CSOs). C-TIP activities contribute to the USG's JSP Goal 1.3 of countering transnational crime threatening U.S. interests by strengthening citizen-responsive governance and respect for human rights. USAID partners with the International Organization for Migration (IOM) to prevent an increase in TIP rates. IOM has gradually built the capacity of 20 local CSOs to deliver prevention and protection services. IOM's approach to managing USAID funds is fully transparent and cost effective while providing a mechanism for transferring USAID funds to local CSOs. FY 2018 funds will support strengthening local service providers, who will organize awareness campaigns, provide consultations to at-risk groups and support services for VOTs. A hotline managed by two leading CSOs will service up to 2,500 calls a year. The hotline provides consultations on safe migration, travel and marriage abroad and basic legal support. It also serves as a mechanism for VOT identification and further referral to state agencies and rehabilitation service providers. USAID will continue support for essential C-TIP services, including the shelter for victims. Up to 100 VOTs will receive rehabilitation and reintegration services. Actual and potential victims will also receive training in safe job-searching.

receiver-org.narrative: International Organisation for Migration

description.narrative: This project uses professional exchanges to establish connections between the people of Belarus and their US colleagues so participants can learn about the advantages and disadvantages of a democratic, free-market economy. Over five years, the project will bring at least 300 participants from Belarus to the United States on three-week exchanges, which will feature tailored trainings, homestays, and community service projects. The project is funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development as a task order under the Focus on Results: Enhancing Capacity across Sectors in Transition II-Participant Training contract (FORECAST II-PT).

description.narrative: Local Capacity Development Program : USAID provides support to local non-governmental organizations (NGOs) to better serve the needs of the society. USAID support aims to increase the sustainability of local NGOs, enhance their advocacy efforts, promote the sustainable development of professional and local communities, and improve the quality of services delivered by NGOs to the communities and to the general public. Activities include organizational capacity development, specialized trainings for NGO management, mentoring and peer-to-peer collaboration, and small grants to NGOs to build capacity to address the development challenges of their professional and local communities.

description.narrative: The project supports the integration and participation of disadvantaged and vulnerable groups in the countrys economic and social life through the development of sustainable community- and family-based social services. A goal is to reduce the number of children in Belarus who are institutionalized in state-administered orphanages and boarding schools by promoting and supporting at-home family care.

description.narrative: The major goal of Business Advocacy in Belarus project (BAB) is to support the democratic process and the transition to a market economy in Belarus through business advocacy efforts.The project increases the ability of independent business organizations to effectively advocate and to engage different groups of business community in joint efforts to promote market reforms in Belarus.The major project product and advocacy tool is the National Business Platform . The Platform is a set of recommendations on legislative changes to improve the business climate. It serves to mobilize the business community and to affect public policy.

description.narrative: To prevent trafficking of persons including, but not limited to, Belarusian women aged 16-25 by raising their awareness of the dangers of trafficking, developing their job-market skills, assisting them in creating small businesses and finding employment; and protection of victims of trafficking (VoTs) by means of long-term reintegration into the society and combating stigma.Note: project started in 2004 but I put 2005 as the system requires it.

description.narrative: Develop and conduct needs assessments, baseline studies, targeted evaluations, special studies or other information-gathering efforts specifically for the design, monitoring and evaluation of USG-funded programs. This sub-element may also include developing and disseminating best practices and lessons learned, testing demonstration and/or pilot models, or the preparation of strategic plans and other short-term programming tasks. Note: All such activities that are carried out by partners as an integral part of their monitoring and evaluation efforts for programs funded under other sub-elements should be included within those sub-elements.

description.narrative: Strengthen the legal, regulatory, institutional, and information environment which protects and enables the growth in associational life and the development of independent and sustainable civil society organizations (CSOs). Build the capacity of civil society organizations to act as agents for reform and support their participation in democratic decision-making through articulating and representing their members interests, engaging in service delivery, and advocating for issues which become part of the public agenda and are reflected in public policies. Encourage the strengthening of a civic culture which supports democratic institutions and processes, active participation in political and civic life, and the civic virtues of tolerance, pluralism, compromise, trust, and respect for individual rights, including gender equality.
